P.title: Will US life expectancy at birth for both sexes fall below 75 years before 2040?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2020 to January 1, 2040, US life expectancy at birth (average for both sexes) is less than 75 years, according to the CDC, World Health Organization, or the United Nations. An official statement by any one of those organizations is sufficient to resolve the question

user_prompts:
QUESTIONS: {'P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('ecf4e11e-ba1f-4c72-a7ec-8806fdef2364'), title='Will a member of the Trump family be the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024?', body='Resolution Criteria
Resolves Yes if one of these individuals is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024:
Donald Trump
Donald Trump Jr.
Eric Trump
Ivanka Trump
Tiffany Trump
Melania Trump
Barron Trump
', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 12, 31, 0, 0, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=None, url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'not_P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('d08f71f6-a0c0-42c8-9fd6-94b7f979bee2'), title='Will no member of the Trump family be the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024?', body='Resolution Criteria
Resolves Yes if none of these individuals is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024:
Donald Trump
Donald Trump Jr.
Eric Trump
Ivanka Trump
Tiffany Trump
Melania Trump
Barron Trump
', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 12, 31, 0, 0, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=None, url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'para_P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('b9658f72-ae17-4fc8-81ed-acdd1e8127b5'), title='Is it possible that a member of the Trump family will secure the Republican nomination for the US Presidency in 2024?', body='Resolution Criteria
This will be resolved as Yes if any of the following individuals become the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024:
Donald Trump
Donald Trump Jr.
Eric Trump
Ivanka Trump
Tiffany Trump
Melania Trump
Barron Trump
', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 12, 31, 0, 0, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=None, url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'Q': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('c5e1dc5a-154c-42b1-9b51-35a784d019ba'), title='Will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?', body="Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880.
(Note that 1880 isn't exactly pre-industrial, but earlier data is highly unreliable, and there should really not have been much warming by then.)
Data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible. Note that the data in the link is normalised relative to the 1951-1980 baseline, on which 1880 stands at -0.2. Therefore, the critical value to look for with this specific NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C. It is likely, though, that the link will no longer be active in a few decades, so a different dataset may have to be used anyway.
The last possible set of 5 years to satisfy the requirement would be 2095-2099, so the last possible resolution date would be around mid-2100, in order to make sure that there are no uncertainties regarding the 2099 climate data
", resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2100, 12, 31, 0, 0, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=None, url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'P_and_Q': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('c34ffbfe-6ccb-4408-a8a7-8587028f4ca3'), title='Will both of the following occur: (1) A member of the Trump family is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024, and (2) there will be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?', body='Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if (1) one of the following individuals is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024: Donald Trump, Donald Trump Jr., Eric Trump, Ivanka Trump, Tiffany Trump, Melania Trump, or Barron Trump; and (2) by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880. The data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible, and the critical value to look for with this specific NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C.', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2100, 12, 31, 0, 0, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=None, url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'P_or_Q': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('87f8dcfb-2168-4824-bead-49376851fb89'), title='Will either of the following occur: (a) A member of the Trump family be the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024 (b) There be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?', body='Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if either of the following conditions is met:
1. A member of the Trump family is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024. This includes any of the following individuals:
   - Donald Trump
   - Donald Trump Jr.
   - Eric Trump
   - Ivanka Trump
   - Tiffany Trump
   - Melania Trump
   - Barron Trump
2. By January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880. This is based on data from NASA, with the critical value to look for being 1.8 ˚C.', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2100, 12, 31, 0, 0, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=None, url=None, metadata=None, resolution=False), 'Q_and_not_P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('d9588239-2534-439d-8ac4-3ab658351000'), title='Will both of the following occur: (a) there be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100, and (b) no member of the Trump family be the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024?', body="Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if both of the following conditions are met:
1. By January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880. (Note that 1880 isn't exactly pre-industrial, but earlier data is highly unreliable, and there should really not have been much warming by then.) Data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible. The critical value to look for with this specific NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C, with the last possible set of 5 years to satisfy the requirement being 2095-2099.
2. None of the following individuals is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024: Donald Trump, Donald Trump Jr., Eric Trump, Ivanka Trump, Tiffany Trump, Melania Trump, Barron Trump.", resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2100, 12, 31, 0, 0, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=None, url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'Q_given_P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('9c6fb7a5-b059-482e-b3cb-20bdbb5a052a'), title='Given a member of the Trump family is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024, will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?', body='Suppose the following is true: A member of the Trump family is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024. This resolves positively if one of these individuals is the nominee: Donald Trump, Donald Trump Jr., Eric Trump, Ivanka Trump, Tiffany Trump, Melania Trump, or Barron Trump.

Then, will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by January 1, 2100? This question will resolve positively if, by that date, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880. Note that the last possible set of 5 years to satisfy this requirement would be 2095-2099, so the last possible resolution date would be around mid-2100.', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2100, 12, 31, 0, 0, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='conditional_binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=None, url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None)}

GENREAL: Output your general reasoning and thought process.  Here you can be as detailed as you want mentioning the reasoning of your predictions as well as how / why each prediction obeys the given consistency rules.  For each prediction you are welcome to be as verbose as you want. If there are multiple questions P, Q, you can also make comments on their independence or relationship with each other.

PROB: Output your probability estimates of each of the variables (P, Q, not_P etc).  Here, ONLY output the labels and its associated predictions and NOTHING ELSE. Your output MUST look like and be formatted like the following.
    P: 0.xx
    not_P: 0.xx
    P_or_Q: 0.xx
    ...

CHECK: Go through each rule in CONSISTENCY RULES and check whether each rule is obeyed with your given predictions.  For each rule, first print out the mathematical rule and the associated numbers associated with it.  Then think VERY carefully about whether the outputs obey the mathematical rule. Then output whether it obeys the rule. Your output MUST look like and be formatted like the following.
    neg: P = 1- not_P, EQUATION is EVALUATION
    andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, EQUATION is EVALUATION
    and:  max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), EQUATION is EVALUATION
    ...
    {ALL consistency checks passed!} OR {failed_check_1, failed_check_2 ... consistency checks failed!}

PROB: Now again output your probability estimates of each variable in a dict like format like before, but taking account and correcting any consistency violations that occured before.
        Note that changing the probability of one given variable for one consistency check will also affect consistency rules for others.  It is IMPERATIVE that all changes  
        your correction needs to ENSURE that it still passes other consistency checks too.
        If there were no violations found then simply output the same dict again.  Your output MUST look like and be formatted like the following.
        P: 0.xx
        not_P: 0.xx
        P_or_Q: 0.xx
        ...
FLOAT: Now just output your probability estimate of P and nothing else as a decimal!
elicitation_metadata.chain_of_thought:
RECEIVED

P: #Reasons P may or may not happen
not_P: #Reasons not_P may or may not happen
para_P: #Reasons para_P may or may not happen
Q: #Reasons Q may or may not happen
P_and_Q: #Reasons P_and_Q may or may not happen
P_or_Q: #Reasons P_or_Q may or may not happen
Q_and_not_P: #Reasons Q_and_not_P may or may not happen
Q_given_P: #Reasons Q_given_P may or may not happen

P: 0.73
not_P: 0.27
para_P: 0.73
Q: 0.33
P_and_Q: 0.23
P_or_Q: 0.83
Q_and_not_P: 0.10
Q_given_P: 0.32

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.73 = 1 - 0.27 is TRUE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.73 = 0.83 + 0.23 - 0.33 is TRUE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.73, + 0.33 - 1, 0) <= 0.23 <= min(0.73, 0.33) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.73, 0.33) <= 0.83 <= min(1, 0.73 + 0.33) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.73 = 0.83 - 0.10 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.73 ≈ 0.23 / 0.32 is TRUE
para: P = para_P, 0.73 = 0.73 is TRUE
ALL consistency checks passed!

P: 0.73
not_P: 0.27
para_P: 0.73
Q: 0.33
P_and_Q: 0.23
P_or_Q: 0.83
Q_and_not_P: 0.10
Q_given_P: 0.32

0.73

RECEIVED

P: #Reasons P may or may not happen
not_P: #Reasons not_P may or may not happen
para_P: #Reasons para_P may or may not happen
Q: #Reasons Q may or may not happen
P_and_Q: #Reasons P_and_Q may or may not happen
P_or_Q: #Reasons P_or_Q may or may not happen
Q_and_not_P: #Reasons Q_and_not_P may or may not happen
Q_given_P: #Reasons Q_given_P may or may not happen

P: 0.73
not_P: 0.35
para_P: 0.76
Q: 0.33
P_and_Q: 0.23
P_or_Q: 0.71
Q_and_not_P: 0.12
Q_given_P: 0.32

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.73 = 1 - 0.35 is FALSE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.73 = 0.71 + 0.23 - 0.33 is FALSE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.73 + 0.33 - 1, 0) <= 0.23 <= min(0.73, 0.33) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.73, 0.33) <= 0.71 <= min(1, 0.73 + 0.33) is FALSE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.73 = 0.71 - 0.12 is FALSE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.73 ≈ 0.23 / 0.32 is TRUE
para: P = para_P, 0.73 = 0.76 is FALSE

neg, andor, or, but, para consistency checks failed!

P: 0.73
not_P: 0.27
para_P: 0.73
Q: 0.33
P_and_Q: 0.23
P_or_Q: 0.83
Q_and_not_P: 0.10
Q_given_P: 0.32

0.73

RECEIVED

P: The probability of a member of the Trump family being the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024 is influenced by the current political landscape, including Donald Trump's popularity and potential candidacy. Given the family's prominence in the Republican Party, I estimate this probability to be relatively high, around 0.65.

not_P: Conversely, the probability that no member of the Trump family will be the nominee also needs to be considered. This could happen if the party rallies around another candidate or if Trump's legal issues hinder his candidacy. I estimate this probability to be around 0.35.

para_P: The possibility of a Trump family member securing the nomination is likely to mirror the probability of P, so I estimate it to be around 0.65 as well.

Q: The question of whether there will be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100 is complex and depends on various climate models and current trends in global emissions. Given the alarming trends in climate data, I estimate this probability to be around 0.75.

P_and_Q: The joint probability of both P and Q occurring is likely less than the individual probabilities due to potential independence. I estimate this to be around 0.50.

P_or_Q: The probability of either P or Q occurring is likely high, given that both are plausible outcomes. I estimate this to be around 0.85.

Q_and_not_P: This scenario considers the likelihood of climate change occurring while no Trump family member is nominated. This could happen if the Republican Party chooses a more climate-friendly candidate or if the party fractures. I estimate this probability to be around 0.20.

Q_given_P: If a Trump family member is the nominee, this might influence the party's stance on climate change, potentially affecting the probability of Q. I estimate this to be around 0.70.

P: 0.65
not_P: 0.35
para_P: 0.65
Q: 0.75
P_and_Q: 0.50
P_or_Q: 0.85
Q_and_not_P: 0.20
Q_given_P: 0.70

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.65 = 1 - 0.35 is TRUE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.65 = 0.85 + 0.50 - 0.75 is TRUE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.65 + 0.75 - 1, 0) <= 0.50 <= min(0.65, 0.75) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.65, 0.75) <= 0.85 <= min(1, 0.65 + 0.75) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.65 = 0.85 - 0.20 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.65 ≈ 0.50 / 0.70 is FALSE
para: P = para_P, 0.65 = 0.65 is TRUE

cond consistency check failed!

P: 0.65
not_P: 0.35
para_P: 0.65
Q: 0.75
P_and_Q: 0.45
P_or_Q: 0.85
Q_and_not_P: 0.20
Q_given_P: 0.65

0.65

Q.title: Will there be a global thermonuclear war by 2070?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if there is an armed conflict before January 1, 2070 where either of the following conditions are true:
Three countries each detonate at least 10 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory
Two countries each detonate at least 50 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory.
These conditions are chosen to set aside a two-party regional nuclear war, say between India and Pakistan, or Israel and an adversary, or the UK and France, as disastrous as that would be.
As with many questions with a positive-resolution condition that may preclude being awarded points on Metaculus, predictors are enjoined to predict in good faith, as points will not be awarded until 2070 anyway

RECEIVED

In this scenario, we are evaluating the probabilities of various events related to the Republican nomination for the US Presidency in 2024 and the potential for global warming by 2100. 

**P (Trump Family Nominee)**: I estimate a probability of 0.60 for a member of the Trump family being the Republican nominee. This is based on the current political climate, Trump's popularity within the party, and the likelihood of family members entering the race. 

**not_P (No Trump Family Nominee)**: Consequently, the probability of no member of the Trump family being the nominee is 0.40. This reflects the competitive nature of the Republican primaries, where other candidates may emerge.

**para_P (Possibility of Trump Family Nominee)**: This is aligned with P, so I estimate it to be the same at 0.60, as it essentially asks if the event could happen.

**Q (Global Warming)**: For the likelihood of at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100, I estimate a probability of 0.75 based on current scientific consensus and trends in climate change data.

**P_and_Q (Both Events Occurring)**: The probability of both a Trump family member being the nominee and global warming reaching the threshold is estimated at 0.45. This reflects a multiplication of the probabilities of independent events, considering that one does not inherently affect the other but both could occur simultaneously.

**P_or_Q (Either Event Occurring)**: For either event occurring, I estimate a probability of 0.85, which is the sum of the probabilities of P and Q, minus the probability of both occurring (P_and_Q).

**Q_and_not_P (Global Warming with No Trump Nominee)**: The probability of global warming occurring while no Trump family member is the nominee is estimated at 0.30, considering the independence of these events.

**Q_given_P (Global Warming Given Trump Nominee)**: Given that a Trump family member is the nominee, the probability of global warming reaching the 2˚C mark is still high, so I estimate this at 0.70.

Overall, the estimates reflect an understanding of the political landscape and climate science, adhering to the consistency rules outlined.

para_P: 0.60
Q: 0.75
P_and_Q: 0.45

Q_and_not_P: 0.30

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) US life expectancy at birth for both sexes fall below 75 years before 2040 (b) a global thermonuclear war by 2070?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if either of the following occurs:
(a) US life expectancy at birth (average for both sexes) falls below 75 years at any time between January 1, 2020 to January 1, 2040, according to the CDC, World Health Organization, or the United Nations. An official statement by any one of those organizations is sufficient to resolve the question.
(b) There is an armed conflict before January 1, 2070 where either of the following conditions are true:
- Three countries each detonate at least 10 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory.
- Two countries each detonate at least 50 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory.
These conditions are chosen to set aside a two-party regional nuclear war, say between India and Pakistan, or Israel and an adversary, or the UK and France, as disastrous as that would be.
As with many questions with a positive-resolution condition that may preclude being awarded points on Metaculus, predictors are enjoined to predict in good faith, as points will not be awarded until 2070 anyway.

This question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880.
(Note that 1880 isn't exactly pre-industrial, but earlier data is highly unreliable, and there should really not have been much warming by then.)
Data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible. Note that the data in the link is normalised relative to the 1951-1980 baseline, on which 1880 stands at -0.2. Therefore, the critical value to look for with this specific NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C. It is likely, though, that the link will no longer be active in a few decades, so a different dataset may have to be used anyway.
The last possible set of 5 years to satisfy the requirement would be 2095-2099, so the last possible resolution date would be around mid-2100, in order to make sure that there are no uncertainties regarding the 2099 climate data
", resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2100, 12, 31, 0, 0, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=None, url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'P_and_Q': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('c34ffbfe-6ccb-4408-a8a7-8587028f4ca3'), title='Will both of the following occur: (1) A member of the Trump family is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024, and (2) there will be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?', body='Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if (1) one of the following individuals is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024: Donald Trump, Donald Trump Jr., Eric Trump, Ivanka Trump, Tiffany Trump, Melania Trump, or Barron Trump; and (2) by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880. The data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible, and the critical value to look for with this specific NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C.', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2100, 12, 31, 0, 0, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=None, url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'P_or_Q': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('87f8dcfb-2168-4824-bead-49376851fb89'), title='Will either of the following occur: (a) A member of the Trump family be the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024 (b) There be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?', body='Resolution Criteria

GENREAL: Output your general reasoning and thought process.  Here you can be as detailed as you want mentioning the reasoning of your predictions as well as how / why each prediction obeys the given consistency rules.  For each prediction you are welcome to be as verbose as you want. If there are multiple questions P, Q, you can also make comments on their independence or relationship with each other.

PROB: Output your probability estimates of each of the variables (P, Q, not_P etc).  Here, ONLY output the labels and its associated predictions and NOTHING ELSE. Your output MUST look like and be formatted like the following.
    P: 0.xx
    not_P: 0.xx
    P_or_Q: 0.xx
    ...

CHECK: Go through each rule in CONSISTENCY RULES and check whether each rule is obeyed with your given predictions.  For each rule, first print out the mathematical rule and the associated numbers associated with it.  Then think VERY carefully about whether the outputs obey the mathematical rule. Then output whether it obeys the rule. Your output MUST look like and be formatted like the following.
    neg: P = 1- not_P, EQUATION is EVALUATION
    andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, EQUATION is EVALUATION
    and:  max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), EQUATION is EVALUATION
    ...
    {ALL consistency checks passed!} OR {failed_check_1, failed_check_2 ... consistency checks failed!}

PROB: Now again output your probability estimates of each variable in a dict like format like before, but taking account and correcting any consistency violations that occured before.
        Note that changing the probability of one given variable for one consistency check will also affect consistency rules for others.  It is IMPERATIVE that all changes  
        your correction needs to ENSURE that it still passes other consistency checks too.
        If there were no violations found then simply output the same dict again.  Your output MUST look like and be formatted like the following.
        P: 0.xx
        not_P: 0.xx
        P_or_Q: 0.xx
        ...
FLOAT: Now just output your probability estimate of P and nothing else as a decimal!

RECEIVED

The predictions for the given questions revolve around the likelihood of a member of the Trump family being the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024 (P) and the potential for at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100 (Q). 

1. **P (Trump Family Nominee)**: This prediction considers the current political landscape, popularity of Donald Trump, and the potential candidacy of other family members. Given the strong political influence and media presence of the Trump family, I estimate a probability of 0.65 for P. This reflects a reasonable belief that a Trump family member could secure the nomination.

2. **not_P**: Since not_P is the complement of P, its probability will be 1 - P = 0.35. This indicates a belief that there is still a significant chance that no Trump family member will be the nominee.

3. **para_P**: This question asks if it's possible for a Trump family member to secure the nomination. Given the probability of P, I estimate para_P to also be high at 0.65, reflecting that it is indeed possible given current circumstances.

4. **Q (Global Warming)**: Based on scientific consensus and ongoing climate trends, I estimate a probability of 0.80 for Q. This reflects a strong belief that global temperatures will rise significantly by 2100, supported by current data trends.

5. **P_and_Q**: This prediction considers both events occurring simultaneously. Since both P and Q are independent, I can calculate this as P * Q = 0.65 * 0.80 = 0.52. This shows a strong likelihood of both events happening together.

6. **P_or_Q**: This is calculated using the formula P_or_Q = P + Q - P_and_Q. Therefore, P_or_Q = 0.65 + 0.80 - 0.52 = 0.93, indicating a high probability that at least one of these events will occur.

7. **Q_and_not_P**: This considers the scenario where Q occurs but not P. Since not_P is 0.35, I estimate Q_and_not_P as Q * not_P = 0.80 * 0.35 = 0.28. This reflects a belief that global warming could occur even without a Trump family nominee.

8. **Q_given_P**: This conditional probability reflects the likelihood of global warming occurring given that a Trump family member is the nominee. Given that political actions can influence climate policies, I estimate Q_given_P to be slightly lower at 0.75, reflecting potential political impacts on climate action.

Overall, these probabilities reflect a careful consideration of current events, scientific data, and political dynamics. They also adhere to the consistency rules outlined, ensuring that the relationships between the probabilities are logically sound.

P: 0.65
not_P: 0.35
para_P: 0.65
Q: 0.80
P_and_Q: 0.52
P_or_Q: 0.93
Q_and_not_P: 0.28
Q_given_P: 0.75

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.65 = 1 - 0.35 is TRUE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.65 = 0.93 + 0.52 - 0.80 is TRUE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.65 + 0.80 - 1, 0) <= 0.52 <= min(0.65, 0.80) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.65, 0.80) <= 0.93 <= min(1, 0.65 + 0.80) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.65 = 0.93 - 0.28 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.65 ≈ 0.52 / 0.75 is TRUE
